revisions.rev:
{{Infobox University | name = University of Louisville | image = | motto = ''It's Happening Here'' | established = 1798 | type = [[Public university|Public]] | president = [[James R. Ramsey]] | city = [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]] | state = [[Kentucky]] | country = [[United States]] | undergrad = 15,125 | postgrad = 4,618 | faculty = 2,074 | staff = 3,875 | campus = Urban | nickname = [[Louisville Cardinals]] | mascot = [[Cardinal Bird (mascot)|Cardinal Bird]] |colors = {{colorbox|#ED1C24}} Louisville [[Red]]
{{colorbox|#F0AB00}} Louisville [[Yellow]]
{{colorbox|#1E1E1E}} Louisville [[Black]]http://louisville.edu/ocm/policies/athletics_styleguide.pdf/at_download/file | endowment = $762 millionAs of June 30, 2009. {{cite web | title = University of Louisville Foundation Finance Committee Meeting Minutes February 28, 2011| work = University of Louisville Foundation Report| publisher = University of Louisville Foundation | url = http://www.louisvillefoundation.org/media/agendas/2011/UofLFoundation-FinanceAgenda_28-Feb11.pdf | accessdate = September 25, 2011}} | athletics = [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] | affiliations = [[Big East Conference]] | website = [http://louisville.edu/ www.louisville.edu] | logo = [[Image:University of Louisville Logo.png|165px]] }} The '''University of Louisville''' is a public [[university]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]], [[Kentucky]]. When founded in 1798, it was the first city-owned public university in the United States and one of the first universities chartered west of the [[Allegheny Mountains]]. The university is mandated by the [[Kentucky General Assembly]] to be a "Preeminent Metropolitan Research University".{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/about/mission.html|title=UofL Mission statement|accessdate=2006-06-08}} U of L enrolls students from 118 of 120 Kentucky counties,{{cite web |url=http://louisville.edu/~jbmorr03/Fall-05-Enrollment-by-County.pdf|title=UofL Fall '05 Enrollment by County|accessdate=2006-06-08 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071201124647/http://louisville.edu/~jbmorr03/Fall-05-Enrollment-by-County.pdf |archivedate=2007-12-01}} all 50 [[U.S. state]]s, and 116 countries around the world.{{cite web |url=http://louisville.edu/~jbmorr03/Fall-05-Enrollment-by-State.pdf |title=UofL Fall '05 Enrollment by State|accessdate=2006-07-07 |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071201124648/http://louisville.edu/~jbmorr03/Fall-05-Enrollment-by-State.pdf |archivedate=2007-12-01}} The University of Louisville Health Sciences Center participated in the development of a highly [[HPV vaccine|effective vaccine]] against cervical cancer in 2006,{{cite web|url=http://januvia.blogspot.com/2006/12/merck-markets-cancer-vaccine.html|title=Merck, Januvia and Blood Pressure Medicine: Merck Markets Cancer Vaccine Discovered by Louisville Doctors}} the first fully self-contained [[artificial heart]] transplant surgery,{{cite web|url=http://www.heartpioneers.org/patient/gallery/conference1.html|title=Robert L. Tools|accessdate=2006-06-08}} the first successful [[hand transplantation]],{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/411618|title=America's First Successful Hand Transplant -- One Year Later|date=2000-01-31|accessdate=2009-03-31|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5fggJ8G6j|archivedate=2009-03-31}} and the development of the [[Pap smear]] test{{Citation needed|reason=Papanicolaou was never at Louisville|date=April 2009}}. The University Hospital (now Jewish University Medical Center) is also credited with the first civilian [[ambulance]], the nation's first accident services, now known as an [[emergency department|emergency room]] (ER), and one of the first [[blood bank]]s in the US.{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/ur/ucomm/mags/summer2000/cover_story.html|title=U of L Magazine - Summer 2000}} Since 1999, U of L has made the largest gains of any university in [[National Institutes of Health]] research ranking, with its NIH funding increasing 277 percent and its rank increasing 30 places.{{cite web|url=http://www.uoflhealthcare.org/ulhc/news_thumbnail/VSEL _for_More_Information.pdf|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5lKPRziai|archivedate=2009-11-16|title=VSEL for More Information|accessdate=2006-06-08|format=PDF}} As of 2006 among public [[Higher education in the United States|U.S. universities]], the [[melanoma]] clinic ranks third, the [[neurology]] research program fourth, and the [[spinal cord]] research program 10th in NIH funding. U of L is also known for the recent success of some of its athletics programs. Since 2000 the Cardinals have made appearances in the men's basketball [[Final Four]] in 2005, football [[Bowl Championship Series]] [[Orange Bowl]] in 2007, the [[College World Series|College Baseball World Series]], mens soccer NCAA runner-up in 2010, and the women's basketball final four (NCAA runner-up in 2009). Its Women's Volleyball has [[three-peat]]ed as champions of the Big East Tournament (2008, 2009, 2010) and its Women's Track and Field program has won Outdoor Big East in 2008, 2009, 2010 and Indoor Big East in 2011. == Academics and innovations == [[Image:Grawhallul.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Modeled after The Jeffersonian Rotunda at the University of Virginia, Grawemeyer Hall features ''[[The Thinker]]'' by [[Auguste Rodin]]]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! ! Year |- | World's first self-contained [[artificial heart]] transplant | 2001 |- | World's first successful hand transplant | 1999 |- | Development of [[Pap Smear]] | 1970 |- | Development of [[Autotransfusion]] | 1935 |- | First [[Emergency Room]] | 1911 |} The University of Louisville offers bachelor's degrees in 70 fields of study, masters' degrees in 78 fields of study, and doctorate degrees in 22 fields of study. The Center for Measuring University Performance at Arizona State University, in its 2009 annual report, ranks U of L in the top public research universities in the United States.The ranking is based on nine different measures: Total Research, Federal Research, Endowment Assets, Annual Giving, National Academy Members, Faculty Awards, Doctorates Granted, Postdoctoral Appointees, and SAT/ACT range.{{cite web|url=http://mup.asu.edu/research2009.pdf |title=Layout 1 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-10-22}} The University ranks in the First Tier by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''.{{cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/national-universities-rankings/state+KY |title=National Universities Rankings - Best College - Education - US News |publisher=Colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date=2010-08-17 |accessdate=2010-10-22}} The school's admission standards are considered "more selective" by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''.{{cite news|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/louisville-ky/university-of-louisville-1999|title=Best Colleges|work=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=2006-06-08}} Academically, U of L boasts a College of Business that is ranked among the top 7 percent in the nation, a dental school ranked in the top 10 regularly according to board scores, [[University of Louisville School of Law|a law school]] tied with two other colleges for the 97th ranking in the nation,a top 100 College of Education and Human Development, and nationally respected programs in engineering, social work, and music. The College of Business at the University of Louisville offers a distinctive Ph.D. program with a concentration in Entrepreneurship. The United States Association for Small Business and Entrepreneurship (USASBE) has named the college its 2010 National Model PhD Entrepreneurship Program award winner. Its programs in Entrepreneurship are ranked among the best in the world, including a Top 20 ranking in 2006, 2007, and 2008 (#17) by US News & World Report, a Top 10 ranking by Entrepreneur Magazine and the Princeton Review, and a Top 26 ranking from Fortune Small Business.{{cite web|url=http://www.ssrn.com/update/mrn/mrnann/annA003.html|title=New Schools Join MRN Business Schools Research Papers Series|accessdate=2008-09-12}}{{Dead link|url=http://www.ssrn.com/update/mrn/mrnann/annA003.html|date=March 2009|note=link shows up on Google search but it is not cached and is firewalled when visited. Wayback links predate September 2008}} UofL is also the only U.S. college to offer a minor in [[African American]] theatre,{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/theatrearts/aatp-certificate.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071225142542/http://louisville.edu/a-s/ta/AATP.html|archivedate=2007-12-25|title=University of Louisvilleâs African American Theatre Program |accessdate=2006-06-08}} among only 21 schools in the U.S. to offer a [[Academic degree|graduate degree]] in [[Pan-Africanism|Pan-African studies]], and among the first five to require public service in its [[law school]] curriculum. The [[Brandeis Medal]] is awarded by the law school's [[Louis Brandeis|Louis D. Brandeis]] Society, and is given in tribute to Brandeis, a former [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] justice from Louisville and the namesake of the university's law school. == History == === Founding and early years: 1798-1845 === [[Image:ULJusticeCen.jpg|thumb|right|260px|U of L Justice Administration Building]] The University of Louisville traces its roots back to 1798{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/about/history.html|title=UofL History|accessdate=2006-06-08}} when the Kentucky General Assembly chartered a school of higher learning in the newly established town of Louisville and ordered the sale of 6,000 acres (24 kmÂ²) of [[South Central Kentucky]] land to pay for its implementation. On April 3, 1798, eight community leaders began local [[Fundraising|fund raising]] for the school, then known as the [[Jefferson Seminary]]. It opened 15 years later in 1813 and offered college and high school level courses in a variety of subjects. It was headed by [[Edward Mann Butler]] from 1813 to 1816, who later headed the first public school in Kentucky in 1829 and is considered Kentucky's first historian. Despite its early success, pressure from newly established public schools and media critiques of it as "elitist" would force its closure in 1829.{{cite web|url=http://lms.jefferson.k12.ky.us/lms-archives/publicschools.html|title='Public Schools' entry from The Encyclopedia of Louisville ( c2001)|accessdate=2009-03-02}} Eight years later, in 1837, the Louisville [[City council]] established the [[Louisville Medical Institute]] at the urging of renowned physician and medical author [[Charles Caldwell (physician)|Charles Caldwell]]. After his dismissal from [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington's]] [[Transylvania University]], Caldwell would lead the LMI into becoming one of the best [[medical school]]s west of the [[Allegheny Mountains]]. In 1840, the Louisville [[Collegiate institute]], a rival medical school, was established after an LMI faculty dispute. It opened in 1844 on land near the present day [[Health science]]s campus. === History as a public municipal university: 1846-1969 === [[Image:Speed Engineering School, Louisville, Kentucky (1067).jpg|thumb|right|280px|The [[J. B. Speed School of Engineering]] on the Belknap Campus]] In 1846 the Kentucky legislature combined the Louisville Medical Institute, the Louisville Collegiate Institution, and a newly created law school into the University of Louisville, on a campus just east of [[Downtown Louisville]]. The LCI folded soon afterwards. The university would experience rapid growth in the 20th century, adding new schools in the liberal arts (1907), [[Graduate school|graduate studies]] (1915), [[dentistry]] (1918), [[engineering]] (1925), [[music]] (1932) and [[social work]] (1936). In 1923, the school purchased what is today the Belknap Campus, where it moved its liberal arts programs and [[University of Louisville School of Law|law school]], with the medical school remaining downtown. The school had attempted to purchase a campus donated by the Belknap family in [[The Highlands (Louisville)|The Highlands]] area in 1917 (where [[Bellarmine University]] is currently located), but a citywide tax increase to pay for it was voted down. The Belknap Campus was named after the family for their efforts. In 1931, U of L purchased the [[Louisville Municipal College]] for Negroes (est. 1879 and now [[Simmons College of Kentucky]]), as a compromise plan to desegregation. As a part of U of L, the school had an equal standing with the school's other colleges. It was dissolved in 1951 when U of L [[desegregation|desegregated]]. During [[World War II]], Louisville was one of 131 colleges and universities nationally that took part in the [[V-12 Navy College Training Program]] which offered students a path to a Navy commission.{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/alumni/scholarships/alumni.html |title=Alumni Association Scholarships |publisher=[[Louisville, Kentucky]]: University of Louisville |last= |first= |accessdate=September 25, 2011 |date=2011}} In the second half of the 20th century, schools were opened for [[business]] (1953), [[education]] (1968), and [[justice]] administration (1969). === History as a public state university: 1970-present === [[Image:LBLawLou.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Brandeis School of Law]] Talk of U of L joining the public [[university system]] of Kentucky began in the 1960s. As a municipally funded school (meaning funding only came from the city of Louisville), the movement of people to the suburbs of Louisville created budget shortfalls for the school and forced tuition prices to levels unaffordable for most students. At the same time, the school's well established medicine and law schools were seen as assets for the state system. Still, there was opposition to U of L becoming public, both from faculty and alumni who feared losing the small, close-knit feel of the campus, and from universities already in the state system who feared funding cuts. After several years of heated debate, the university joined the state system in 1970, a move largely orchestrated by then [[List of Governors of Kentucky|Kentucky governor]] and U of L alumnus [[Louie Nunn]].{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/ur/ucomm/mags/fall98/archives.html|title=Going State|accessdate=2006-06-08}} The first years in the public system were difficult, as enrollment skyrocketed while funding was often insufficient. Several programs were threatened with losing accreditation due to a lack of funding, although schools of [[nursing]] (1979) and urban & [[Public administration|public affairs]] (1983) were added. [[Image:ULreshall.jpg|thumb|left|240px|Stevenson Hall on the Belknap Campus]] [[John W. Shumaker]] was named U of L's president in 1995. Shumaker was a very successful [[fund raiser]], and quickly increased the school's endowment from $183 to $550 million. He also developed the REACH program{{cite web|url=http://www.reach.louisville.edu/about/ |title=About REACH |publisher=Reach.louisville.edu |date= |accessdate=2009-08-05}} to encourage retention. In 1997, he hired [[Athletic director|athletics director]] [[Tom Jurich]], who restored the athletics program and raised over $100 million to raze abandoned factories and old parking lots next to campus and replace them with on-campus athletic facilities, which vastly improved the aesthetics of the Belknap Campus. Academically, U of L moved closer to parity with the state's flagship [[University of Kentucky]] as retention rates and research funding increased, and average GPAs and ACT scores were much higher for incoming freshman. The school's current and 17th president is [[James R. Ramsey]], the former state budget director. Ramsey has continued the endowment and fund raising growth started by Shumaker, but added more emphasis on improving the physical aspects of the Belknap Campus. To this end, he started a million dollar "campus beautification project" which painted six overpasses on the Belknap Campus with a 'U of L theme' and planted over 500 trees along campus streets, and doubled the number of on-campus housing units. The school's federal [[research funding]] has also doubled under Ramsey, and three buildings have been built for nanotechnology and medical research. UofL's [[retention rate]]s have also increased from 30 percent in 1999 to 40 percent in 2006. [[Image:Belknap Research Building, University of Louisville (1058).jpg|thumb|right|280px|The Belknap Research Building, completed in 2005]] === UPS tuition reimbursement and Metropolitan College === In addition to their nationwide partial tuition reimbursement programs, [[United Parcel Service|UPS]] (United Parcel Service) offers U of L (along with [[Jefferson Community and Technical College]]) students who work overnight at [[Worldport (UPS air hub)|Worldport]], the company's worldwide air hub at [[Louisville International Airport]], full tuition reimbursement through a program called Metropolitan College. This program also offers reimbursement for $65.00 of book costs for each class, and awards bonus checks to students in good standing at the end of each semester and upon reaching certain credit hour milestones. Employees additionally are eligible for full health insurance coverage.{{cite web|url=http://www.metro-college.com/|title=Metropolitan College|accessdate=2006-06-08}} Currently over 75 percent of the workers at the air hub are students.{{cite news|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/1766263741.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=May+18,+2006&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=UPS+fuels+economic+gains|title=UPS fuels economic gains|accessdate=2006-06-08|date=2006-05-18|work=Courier}} === Schools and colleges === The university now consists of 12 different schools and colleges (year founded): * [http://louisville.edu/artsandsciences/ College of Arts and Sciences] (1907) * [http://business.louisville.edu/ College of Business] (1953) * [http://louisville.edu/education/ College of Education and Human Development] (1968) * [http://graduate.louisville.edu/ Graduate School] (1918) * [[J. B. Speed School of Engineering]] (1925) * [http://louisville.edu/kent/ Kent School of Social Work] (1936) * [[Louis D. Brandeis School of Law]] (1846) * [http://louisville.edu/dental/ School of Dentistry] (1887) * [http://louisville.edu/medschool/ School of Medicine] (1837) * [http://louisville.edu/music/ School of Music] (1932) * [http://louisville.edu/nursing/ School of Nursing] (1979) * [http://louisville.edu/sphis/ School of Public Health and Information Sciences] (1968) == The campuses == The university has three campuses: === Belknap Campus === [[Image:CardParkKY.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Completed in 2001, Cardinal Park is home to 5 Cardinal athletic teams]] Acquired in 1923, the '''Belknap Campus''' (pronounced "Bel-nap" with the K silent) is the school's main campus. It is located three miles (5 km) south of downtown Louisville in the [[Old Louisville]] neighborhood. It houses seven of the 12 academic colleges and contains one of the casts of [[Auguste Rodin]]'s ''[[The Thinker]]'' in front of the main administrative building, Grawemeyer Hall. The grounds of the campus were originally used as an orphanage, several of the original buildings used.{{cite web|url=http://library.louisville.edu/uarc/digre/refuge.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060904105011/http://library.louisville.edu/uarc/digre/refuge.html|archivedate=2006-09-04|title=University of Louisville Buildings Once Housed Homeless Children|accessdate=2008-01-16}} The Belknap Campus has expanded greatly in recent years, with land housing abandoned factories in the area being purchased and redeveloped. Projects built since 1998 include [[Papa John's Cardinal Stadium]] and adjacent Trager Center fieldhouse, Owsley B. Frazier Cardinal Park (which includes Ulmer Stadium for softball, Trager Stadium for field hockey, Cardinal Track and Soccer Stadium, Bass-Rudd Tennis Center, locker rooms, a playground and a cushioned walking path), [[Jim Patterson Stadium]] for baseball, Ralph R. Wright Natatorium, Owsley Brown Frazier [[Sports medicine]] Center, and a lacrosse stadium. With new parking at Papa John's Cardinal Stadium, non-resident parking was moved there and the [[parking lot]]s near campus were redeveloped with new dormitory buildings, including the [http://www.aoinc.com/content/casestudies/cs2.cfm?return=1 Bettie Johnson Apartments], Kurz Hall, Minardi Hall, and {{cite web |url=http://www.louisville.edu/student/communitypark/ |title=Community Park |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20070624001533/http://www.louisville.edu/student/communitypark/ |archivedate=2007-06-24}}. [[Image:ULquad2.jpg|thumb|left|270px|The Quad on the Belknap Campus]] Other points of interest on the Belknap Campus include the [https://louisville.edu/planetarium/ Rauch Planetarium], the Covi Gallery of the Hite Art Institute, and the final resting place for former U.S. Supreme Court Justice [[Louis Brandeis|Louis D. Brandeis]] under the portico in the Brandeis Law School. Surrounded by, but not part of the campus, are the [[Speed Art Museum]], a private institution not affiliated with the University of Louisville, and the [[Confederate Monument in Louisville|Confederate Civil War Monument]], located at the juncture of 2nd and 3rd streets, which honors [[Confederate States Army|Confederate]] [[American Civil War|Civil War]] dead; this was built there before the school grew to surround the land it stands on, which is owned by [[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville Metro]]. The Kentucky State [[Data center]], the state's official [[wikt:clearing house|clearing house]] for census data and estimates, is located next to Bettie Johnson Hall. In 2008 the school purchased two large tracts of land adjacent to the Belknap Campus, {{convert|55|acre|m2}} to the school's northwest and {{convert|30|acre|m2}} south of the Speed School of Engineering. Construction has already began on the northwest segment, with housing for 3,000 students planned. A historic building at 7th Street and Shipp Avenue will be converted into a parking garage for the new residents. No formal plans have yet been made for the southern segment. Private developers are also planning to build an eight-story student apartment building on recently acquired land on Floyd Street just north of Brandeis Street. Image:UofL clocktower and SAC.jpg|U of L Student Activities Center and Clock Tower File:University of Louisville, Belknap Campus, from Eastern Parkway overpass.jpg|Belknap Campus from the Eastern Parkway overpass Image:Rausch Planetarium, University of Louisville (1032).jpg|Rauch Planetarium Image:ULLutzHall.jpg|Lutz Hall is home to the departments of Geography, Anthropology, and Engineering ==== Belknap Campus Development projects ==== [[Image:ProvinceULou.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Construction for 2,000 new student housing units on Shipp Avenue on July 16, 2008]] Several important projects are under construction or planned in the near future, including the reconstruction of the [[Interstate 65|I-65]] ramps to the Belknap Campus, converting the four lanes of [[Parkways of Louisville, Kentucky#Eastern Parkway|Eastern Parkway]] into a two-lane road with bike lanes and a landscaped median to improve pedestrian access to the [[J. B. Speed School of Engineering|Speed School]], the moving of several university offices to allow the existing facilities at Arthur Street and Brandeis Avenue to be converted to [[commercial property]] and restaurants. The [[Yum! Brands|Yum!]] Center (a men's basketball and volleyball practice facility) was completed in the fall of 2007. A {{convert|12000|sqft|m2|sing=on}} [[Olympic sports]] training/rehab center adjacent to Trager Stadium is also under construction. Additionally, Trager Plaza, a small plaza with a fountain, statue, and garden is being built by the Trager Family on the south part of campus. [[Image:ULOvalRecnrst.jpg|thumb|left|250|Reconstruction of The Oval at 3rd Street on July 16, 2008]] ==== International Campus ==== University of Louisville offers Bachelor's Degree and Master's Degrees studying completely in Panama City,Panama or by taking the last two years at the University of Louisville's main campus www.qlu.ac.pa The university also offers their Professional MBA programs in several other countries including Hong Kong, Singapore and other parts of Asia. Their collaboration partner in Singapore is Aventis School of Management [http://www.aventis.edu.sg/ www.aventis.edu.sg] {{-}} Image:ULHonHal.jpg|Construction on Scholar's Hall on Lee Street, June 2008 Image:ULSta.jpg|Expansion of the Field Hockey stadium Image:AMStandBldUL.jpg|Historic building on 7th Street being converted into a parking garage === Health Sciences Campus === [[Image:Picture 159ULHSCPreston.jpg|thumb|right|[[Preston Street (Louisville)|Preston Street]] on the U of L Med Campus]] The U of L Health Sciences Center, also called the med campus, is located just east of [[Downtown Louisville]] in the Louisville medical park which contains two other major hospitals and several specialty hospitals, and it houses the remaining five colleges. This is the school's original campus, being continuously used since 1846, although none of the original buildings remain. Buildings of note on the HSC include the fourteen story Medical Research Tower and the ten-story Jewish University Hospital.Construction is finished for a recently-opened, downtown Louisville Cardiovascular Research Innovation Institute building to be directed by a researcher, Stuart Williams from the [[University of Arizona]]; and an eight story, $70 million [[biomedical research]] building. Faculty and students also work with neighboring hospitals including Kosair Children's Hospital, as well as outreach programs throughout Kentucky, including in [[Paducah, Kentucky|Paducah]], [[Campbellsville, Kentucky|Campbellsville]], and [[Glasgow, Kentucky|Glasgow]]. File:Jewish University Hospital.jpg|U of L Hospital File:Cardiovascular Innovation Institute, University of Louisville.jpg|Cardiovascular Innovation Institute Image:ULMedTower.jpg|U of L Medical Research Tower File:University of Louisville Baxter Research Building.jpg|Baxter Research Building on the U of L Health Sciences Campus Image:Picture 154ULMedPlaza.jpg|Jewish University Hospital Medical Plaza, completed in June 2008 ==== Health Sciences Campus Development projects ==== The U of L Health Sciences Campus has seen a large amount of new development in the past decade, include the completion of 3 new buildings (Baxter Research Complex, Cardiovascular Research Tower, and the Jackson Street Medical Plaza). Work is ongoing on the Biolab Research Tower, with a January 2009 completion date projected. In 2007 U of L announced plans to turn the 30 square block [[Haymarket (Louisville)|Haymarket]] site along I-65 in [[Downtown Louisville]] into a medical research plaza with {{convert|1000000|sqft|m2}} of research space. The project is expected to cost $300 million dollars and would be constructed from 2009 to 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/stories/2007/08/06/story1.html|title=Making hay: Haymarket project would represent nearly $300 million investment on East Jefferson|last=Green|first=Ed|date=2007-08-03|work=Business First of Louisville|accessdate=2009-03-02}} An important project adjacent to the Health Sciences Campus was the conversion of the [[Clarksdale Housing Project|Clarksdale Public Housing Project]] into a new mixed income project dubbed [[Liberty Green (Louisville, Kentucky)|Liberty Green]]. Image:Picture 161ULResearchTower.jpg|The eight story research tower is complete Image:Picture 162ULBioLabConstr.jpg|Construction has just begun on the 10 story Bio Lab Tower === Shelby Campus === The {{convert|230|acre|km2|sing=on}} Shelby Campus is located on [[U.S. Route 60|Shelbyville Road]] near [[Kentucky Route 1747|Hurstbourne Parkway]] in Eastern Louisville. This campus was originally the home of Kentucky Southern College, a [[Southern Baptist Convention|Southern Baptist]] [[liberal arts]] college that operated from 1961 to 1969.{{cite web|url=http://special.library.louisville.edu/display-collection.asp?ID=802 |title=UofL - Kentucky Southern College records |publisher=Special.library.louisville.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-10-22}} After the college folded, it transferred all its assets and liabilities to U of L. It currently only has three buildings which are used for night classes and seminars, although construction of a $34.6-million Center for Predictive Medicine, a Level 3 biosafety facility is in the works.{{cite web|url= http://louisville.edu/community/biosafetylab/ |title= Bio Safety Lab }} The Shelby Campus is also home for the building which houses the Information Technology Resource Center (ITRC) for [[Homeland security]]. The ITRC conducts communications and IT research for the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] as well as seminars and training in [[Emergency management|emergency preparedness]] and response.{{cite web|url=http://www.TheiTRC.com/ |title=theitrc.com |date= |accessdate=2009-08-05}} The U of L Shelby campus is undergoing a major renovation, with two new entrances to the campus off Hurstbourne Parkway. The overall goal is to develop {{convert|108|acre|km2}} of the {{convert|230|acre|km2|sing=on}} campus for business, office, technology and research use, now known as the '''ShelbyHurst Research and Office Park'''. The university will spend $7.9 million on the road improvements on the campus. The roadway improvements began in August 2008, with work on a new four-lane boulevard through the campus, bordered by bike lanes, sidewalks, and will be heavily landscaped.{{cite web|url= http://php.louisville.edu/news/news.php?news=1204 |title= Shelby Campus infrastructure }} === Panama campus and other facilities === [[File:University of Louisville in Panama.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Campus in Panama city]] The University of Louisville also runs a sister campus{{cite web|url=http://web.archive.org/web/20080108144508rn_1/louisville.edu/a-s/cml/las/channing/ |title=Channing Slate's Homepage |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=2008-01-08 |accessdate=2009-08-05}} in [[Panama City]], [[Panama]], which has an MBA program.{{cite web|url=http://cm.cbpa.louisville.edu/content.asp?id=148|title=University of Louisville College of Business}} The full-time program takes around 16 months to complete and enrolls about 200 students. It is currently ranked the 4th best MBA program in [[Latin America]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/stories/2005/10/24/daily6.html|title=U of L Business School earns new rankings|accessdate=2006-06-08 | date=2005-10-24}} U of L recently opened another MBA program in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. The school also operates the [[Moore Observatory]] in [[Oldham County, Kentucky|Oldham County]], which is used for space viewing. There are also plans to purchase several hundred acres in [[Oldham County, Kentucky|Oldham County]] for the school's [[equine]] program. === Libraries === [[File:Ekstrom Library.jpg|thumb|right|205px|The Belknap Campus' Ekstrom Library]] [[Image:Picture 160ULMedLibrary.jpg||thumb|right|205px|The Health Science Campus' Kornhauser Library]] The University of Louisville library system is a member of the [[Association of Research Libraries]], a fraternity of the nation's top college libraries.{{cite web|url=http://www.arl.org/arl/membership/members.shtml#L|title=Member Libraries|accessdate=2009-03-02}} UofL's main library branch is the [[William F. Ekstrom Library]], which opened in 1981. The four story building finished an expansion in March 2006, which increased its total size to {{convert|290000|sqft|m2}} and shelving capacity to over 1.3 million books. It is one of only five universities in the U.S. to have a robotic retrieval system,{{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/library/ekstrom/tour/floor1/robot.html|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20080108134648rn_1/louisville.edu/library/ekstrom/tour/floor1/robot.html|archivedate=2009-07-13|title=Robotic Retrieval System |accessdate=2006-06-08}} which robotically places books in humidity-free bins. There are five other libraries at the university, with a combined total of more than 400,000 volumes of work: * [http://louisville.edu/library/art/ The Margaret M. Bridwell Art Library] * [http://louisville.edu/library/music/ Dwight Anderson Memorial Music Library] * [http://louisville.edu/library/kornhauser/ Kornhauser Health Sciences Library] * [http://www.law.louisville.edu/library/ Brandeis Law School Library] * [http://louisville.edu/library/archives/ University Archives and Center] The old Kersey Library Building will be converted to an academic building for the [[J. B. Speed School of Engineering]]. The Kersey Library collection was fully integrated into Ekstrom Library on January 15, 2007. == Residence Halls == The university has 12 University housing options: === Bettie Johnson Hall === 401 West Cardinal Blvd. Louisville, KYâ (502) 854-2417â === Billy Minardi Hall === 2040 South 4th Street Louisville, KYâ (502) 854-9011â === Community Park === 2033 South 4th Street Louisville, KYâ (502) 854-9011 === Herman & Heddy Kurz Hall === 1900 South 4th Street Louisville, KYâ (502) 854-9011 === The Province === 600 Ruggles Place Louisville, KY 40208 (502) 636-1688 === The Bellamy === 1501 Bellamy Place Louisville, KY 40208 502.634.5996. === Cardinal Towne === Located on 1830 S 3rd Street is the University of Louisville's newest apartment style housing residences. Opening to over 400 students on August 15th, 2011, the project has been a big success and has started expanding already. With assorted restaurants on the 1st floor such as Qdobas, HomeRun Burger, Comfy Cow, etc. === Louisville Hall === 318 Brandeis Avenue Lousiville, KY 40292 === Miller Hall === === Unitas Tower === === Threlkeld Hall === === Wellness House === === Center Hall === == Media == U of L's student maintained radio station, [http://louisville.edu/rso/wlcv/ WLCV], began airing in 1968 and is broadcast on the internet and on a low level AM signal that reaches most of the Belknap Campus.{{cite news |last=Greenwell |first=Patrick |url=http://www.louisvillecardinal.com/2.6449/frequency-after-initial-static-campus-radio-receives-good-reception-1.724955|title=Frequency: After initial static, campus radio receives good reception |publisher=[[The Louisville Cardinal]] |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2008-03-18}} U of L holds a prominent role in the city of Louisville's "Public Radio Partnership" which features three [[National Public Radio|NPR]] stations under one roof, including the school's namesake [[WUOL-FM]] which broadcasts [[classical music]]. The school also holds one-third of the seats on the Partnership's [[board of directors]]. There is also an independent student-run [[weekly newspaper]], ''[[The Louisville Cardinal]]''. The newspaper was originally founded in 1926, and has maintained financial and editorial independence since 1980. The newspaper is overseen by a board of local media professionals and run by a student [[Editing|editor in chief]]. Inside U of L's Student Activities Center is The Floyd Theatre, a 228 seat movie theater operated by the Student Activities Board. The theater is capable of running both 35 mm prints and DVD projection. The Floyd features a Thursday night film and another on Saturday & Sunday nights. Also, there is a recently instituted monthly Midnight Movie that runs on the last Friday of every month. The theater primarily shows independent and foreign films that get limited or no run in Louisville's many commercial theaters. Shows are open to all students, as well as the public. == Greek life == [[Image:ComParkLKY.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Community Park Greek residence hall on 4th Street]] {{multicol}} ; '''Sororities''' * [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] Chapter Beta Epsilon * [[Alpha Omicron Pi]] 1983 Chapter Pi Alpha * [[Alpha Sigma Kappa]] 2000 Chapter Gamma * [[Chi Omega]] 1929 Chapter Beta Gamma * [[Delta Phi Epsilon (social)|Delta Phi Epsilon]] 1927 (closed since 1951) * [[Delta Sigma Theta]] 1922 Chapter Xi * [[Delta Zeta]] 1928 Chapter Beta Gamma * [[Kappa Delta]] 1928 Chapter Alpha Xi * [[Pi Beta Phi]] 1925 Chapter Kentucky Alpha * [[Sigma Kappa]] 1922 Chapter Alpha Theta * [[Sigma Gamma Rho]] Chapter Eta Omega * [[Zeta Phi Beta]] Chapter Delta Theta * [[Zeta Tau Alpha]] 1927 (closed since 1977) {{multicol-break}} ; '''Fraternities''' * [[Alpha Phi Omega]] 1946 Chapter Delta Theta * [[Alpha Tau Omega]] Colonized February 2011 * [[Beta Theta Pi]] 1971 Chapter Delta Pi * [[Delta Upsilon]] 1921 Chapter Sigma Chi Sigma * [[Iota Phi Theta]] 2001 Chapter Epsilon Iota * [[Kappa Alpha Psi]] 1933 Chapter Alpha Omicron * [[Kappa Sigma]] 1983 Chapter Mu Eta * [[Lambda Chi Alpha]] 1948 Chapter Zeta Sigma Zeta * [[Omega Psi Phi]] Chapter Phi Eta * [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] 1993 Chapter Kappa Zeta * [[Phi Delta Theta]] 2007 Chapter Kentucky Iota * [[Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia]] 1995 Chapter Zeta Kappa * [[Phi Kappa Tau]] 1947 Chapter Beta Beta * [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] 1999 Chapter Kentucky Sigma * [[Sigma Chi]] 1989 Chapter Iota Lambda * [[Sigma Pi]] Colonized March 2009 * [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] 1947 Chapter Kentucky Beta * [[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] 1942 Chapter Alpha Chi * [[Triangle Fraternity|Triangle]] 1941 Chapter Louisville {{multicol-end}} == Enrollment statistics == {{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/about/profile.html|title=UofL Profile|accessdate=2006-06-08}} === Undergraduate student body === * Total enrollment is 21,841 as of Fall 2006. * 79.7% of students are [[Kentucky]] residents. * 48.8% of students are from [[Jefferson County, Kentucky|Jefferson County]] (down from 64% in 1995) * Average ACT Score: 24.4 (up from 20.7 in 1995) * 6 year graduation rate: 48.8% (up from 33% in 2004) * Average full time undergrad age: 21.5 years * Percent of undergrads 25 and older: 20% * Percent of undergrads that are full time: 97% * 46.8% Male * 53.2% Female === Demographics === * 77.4% White non Hispanic * 10.9% African American * 5.2% Asian American * 5.4% International students * 1.1% Multi-racial === Top 10 Kentucky counties for enrollment, Fall 2009 === [[Image:UofL2008.png|thumb|right|300px|2008 enrollment map]] [[Image:UL1986.gif|thumb|right|300px|1986 enrollment map]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rank County !County !2009 Enrollment url=http://louisville.edu/institutionalresearch/institutional-research-planning/Factbook%202009-10%203-16-11.pdf !1998 Enrollment |- | 1 | [[Jefferson County, Kentucky|Jefferson]] ([[Louisville, Kentucky|Louisville]]) | '''10,196''' | '''12,623''' |- | 2 | [[Oldham County, Kentucky|Oldham]] ([[La Grange, Kentucky|La Grange]]) | '''832''' | '''705''' |- | 3 | [[Hardin County, Kentucky|Hardin]] ([[Elizabethtown, Kentucky|Elizabethtown]]) | '''707''' | '''728''' |- | 4 | [[Bullitt County, Kentucky|Bullitt]] ([[Shepherdsville, Kentucky|Shepherdsville]]) | '''533''' | '''470''' |- | 5 | [[Fayette County, Kentucky|Fayette]] ([[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]]) | '''495''' | '''279''' |- | 6 | [[Kenton County, Kentucky|Kenton]] ([[Covington, Kentucky|Covington]]) | '''447''' | '''158''' |- | 7 | [[Boone County, Kentucky|Boone]] ([[Florence, Kentucky|Florence]] | '''312''' | '''85''' |- | 8 | [[Shelby County, Kentucky|Shelby]] ([[Shelbyville, Kentucky|Shelbyville]]) | '''278''' | '''212''' |- | 9 | [[Daviess County, Kentucky|Daviess]] ([[Owensboro, Kentucky|Owensboro]]) | '''273''' | '''154''' |- | 10 | [[Nelson County, Kentucky|Nelson]] ([[Bardstown, Kentucky|Bardstown]]) | '''240''' | '''257''' |- |} === Top five International countries for enrollment, Fall 2006 === # [[Panama]] '''196'''* # [[China]] '''159''' # [[India]] '''148''' # [[Egypt]] '''69''' # [[Canada]] '''41''' === Top five US states (other than KY) for enrollment, Fall 2006 === # [[Indiana]] '''1,380'''** # [[Ohio]] '''197''' # [[Florida]] '''132''' # [[Tennessee]] '''121''' # [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] '''114''' ''Note:'' *Panama enrollment includes UofL's [[Panama City]] campus, which offers a full time MBA program.{{cite web|url=http://europe.vault.com/graddegree/school/school_main.jsp?program_id=13707&co_page=2&ch_id=255&tlist=&pt=3|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20071227103219/http://europe.vault.com/graddegree/school/school_main.jsp?program_id=13707&co_page=2&ch_id=255&tlist=&pt=3|archivedate=2007-12-27|title=University of Louisville-Panama|accessdate=2009-03-02}} ''Note:'' **Beginning in 1998, as part of a reciprocity agreement with Indiana University Southeast in New Albany, Indiana, U of L began offering in-state tuition to residents of Clark, Floyd, Harrison, Washington, and Crawford counties in Indiana (residents of Metro Louisville wishing to attend IUS receive the same benefit) {{cite web|url=http://louisville.edu/ur/ucomm/mags/winter99/journal.html|title=UofL Magazine: Journal|accessdate=2009-03-02}} == Notable U of L Alumni == {{main|List of University of Louisville people}} == Athletics == {{main|Louisville Cardinals}} [[Image:Papa john's cardinal stadium.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Pre game ceremonies at [[Papa John's Cardinal Stadium]]]] [[Image:UofL Cardinals Cheerleader.jpg|thumb|right|150px|University of Louisville Cardinals cheerleader]] The [[Louisville Cardinals]] (commonly referred to as "the Cards") are the student athletes representing the university. There are 13 women's and 10 men's teams that participate in the [[Big East Conference]]. The Cardinals are well known nationally as a power in [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|men's basketball]] with two national championships and eight Final Four appearances, in addition to being the most profitable [[College basketball|NCAA basketball]] program (with a net annual revenue of $18.5 million),{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncaa/news/story?id=2337810|title=NCAA might face damages in hundreds of millions|last=Farrey|first=Tom|date=2006-02-21|work=ESPN The Magazine|accessdate=2009-03-02}} ranking 5th in NCAA Tournament wins, 9th in winning percentage, and 5th in annual attendance every year since 1984. The current head coach of the men's basketball team is [[Rick Pitino]]. In recent years other Cardinal teams have gained national prominence. The women's basketball team, led by first team All American [[Angel McCoughtry]], have been to two straight Sweet 16's and have been ranked in the top 10. In December 2008 the Lady Cardinals broke the Big East paid attendance record when 17,000 fans filled Freedom Hall to watch the Cards defeat rival Kentucky. Other U of L teams with recent post season success includes track and field (two individual national championships), volleyball (consecutive Sweet 16 appearances and a [[three-peat]] as Big East Tournament Champions from 2008â2010), and baseball (a College World Series appearance and consecutive Big East conference titles). All U of L locally broadcast games airing on the school's flagship affiliate [[WHAS-TV|WHAS-TV Louisville]] are televised on every cable provider in Kentucky. {{multicol}} '''Football all-time bowl appearances (15)''' * 2010 {{multicol-break}} '''Men's Basketball NCAA national championships (2)''' * 1986 '''Men's Basketball NCAA Final Fours (8)''' Never {{multicol-end}} == Fight song == Notable among a number of songs commonly played and sung at various events such as [[graduation|commencement]], [[convocation]], and athletic games is the University of Louisville [[fight song]], ''Fight! U of L!'' Also notable is ''All Hail'', a fight song written by current Athletic Pep Band director Al Greener. == See also == * [[The University of Louisville Marching Band|The University of Louisville "RED RAGE!" Marching Band]] * [[The University of Louisville Cardinal Singers]] * [[The University of Louisville Collegiate Chorale]] * [[History of Louisville, Kentucky]] * [[McConnell Center]] == References ==
